Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
Comments_List: How to read and comprehend difficult scientific papers, as well as impressively large foundational knowledge on various cancers and their genetic origins.
An intro to cancer biology, how to read biology primary literature, some biochemistry lab techniques
I learned a lot of interesting information about cancer.

I learned so much from this class! We read landmark scientific papers about signaling pathways in cancer, metastasis, immunotherapy, and major events in drug development. We also learned how to write a grant proposal. Overall, it was an incredibly interesting course, and I learned more biology from this class than I did in the entire intro bio sequence.
Experiment design,  critical thinking

I learned about various aspects and types of cancer, especially the mechanisms of how some cancers work and how the treatment works. For example, we talked about retinoblastomas, oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, immunotherapy, metastases, and more. I developed problem solving skills and how to think critically about science. Between this class and reading the Emperor of All Maladies, I think my insight into cancer in general has changed to be more open-minded. I now know more about science and cancer, and I think the class has developed me as a person. We also learned about how to write a grant proposal and how to read science papers. The exposure I got from this class to biology and thinking about cancer was so in depth and amazing.
How to read scientific papers, how to draft a grant proposal.
I learned how to read scientific papers and write a grant proposal. I was also provided a large overview of cancer and it doesnt seem daunting anymore.

How to read analyze and understand scientific papers, write a smashin grant proposal, understand history of cancer in American and global context, figure out ways to target cancer at a molecular level

Important experimental techniques used in Molecular biology, a deep understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in the progression of cancer, how to critically analyze the data presented in a primary research paper, and how to write one's own research proposal in the biological sciences.
I learned so much about biology, cancer, careers in the molecular biology field, and using resources at yale.
Everything from the in-depth mechanisms of cancer biology, to writing a research proposal, to random helpful life advice from Dean Chang.

I learned a lot about the origin, mechanism, and ways to fight cancer. I also learned valuable skills for scientific research, such as reading academic papers, writing a grant proposal, and thinking critically about experimentation. I gained a deeper understanding of how scientific research happens, as well as the various biological assays that are used in molecular biology.

We went through the parts of what contributes to cancer development and functioning. We also learned a lot about laboratory and research methods associated with cancer but also with lab work in general.

This was the best course I've taken at Yale so far--extremely challenging but manageable. I gained a huge amount of knowledge, not to mention the ability to read scientific papers and write grant proposals.
Amazing class, I wish the midterms were shorter.
great course

The strength of this course is Dean Chang and his passion not just for the subject, but for his students. He gives great lectures on super interesting topics, encourages us to ask questions, and makes every effort to get to know us outside of class. He is a truly amazing professor and person, and this class is not only really, really cool for its subject matter, but overall a wonderful experience.
PSETS were a bit long, overall loved the course

There are multiple strengths to this course. I think the greatest strength is the professor, Dean Chang, who is so engaging. He makes the lectures so interesting and fascinating to learn about the concepts. He makes the class interactive, and my classmates have bonded so much over the class. He is really patient and encouraging when you ask questions, and he is generous in providing you help and advice. Another strength was the rigor of the course and how it was set up so you would learn various skills. Each week, we had to read a landmark paper and complete a challenging pset. I think reading the papers and doing the pset really pushed me to think more about science, biology, and cancer and to problem solve. It allowed me to apply information and discuss with classmates how to solve certain problems. The papers are all extremely interesting. Furthermore, you learn to be more active and think more critically whether it is by asking more questions or going on the trip to NYC with the class. You learn so much about cancer, and you gain an increased appreciation for science. The only weakness is sometimes we asked so many questions that the end of the lecture was kind of rushed, and some of the pset questions can be a bit more clear.
The teacher is very invested in his students, and constantly asked for feedback to improve his course. He was also very effective at answering questions and fostering a positive seminar environment.
This will be one of the best classes you take at Yale. Small class size and the most engaging professor - what more could you want?
Long psets that arent the clearest

Incredibly detailed and engaging lectures. Dean Chang is an inspiring professor. Definitely take this class if you are at all interested in Biology. The only weakness I could think of is that in a couple lectures, he allowed students to ask so many questions in class that we were not able to get through all the material that day.
Sometimes the class went very fast but I think I was underprepared in my biology background so it might have just been me.

I think the strength of this course lay in that it was a graduate school like paper discussion seminar, making it very engaging for someone interested in biology. Additionally, the emphasis placed on scientific research skills, culminating in a research proposal, prepared us very well for the future research.

There were many strengths of this course. Covering a wide variety of topics meant a broad understanding of various aspects of cancer, ranging from the hallmarks of cancer to methods we have for fighting cancer. The course was also structured such that we read a lot of scientific papers, which helped increase both my skills in reading these papers and my knowledge of the current topics in cancer research. The grant proposal as an assignment helped me learn how to write a grant proposal, using concepts that were learned in class. 

There weren't any weaknesses to this course, other than possibly that we didn't have the time to go more in-depth in the cancer topics, and it may have been difficult for students who didn't have experience reading scientific papers to get through the papers Dr. Chang assigned.

Topics in Cancer Biology was a great course. It was well organized for learning and Professor Chang made sure to incorporate the classes' feedback into developing his curriculum throughout the semester. Cancer is a huge topic that could not be possibly covered in a semester but this course gave us a very good tidbit of each topic introduced. For example, we could be studying telomeres and their relation to cancer one week and then be studying metastasis (how cancer spreads) the next. Each topic was introduced clearly and we spent just the right amount of time on each one. Overall, this course was superb and the only suggestion would be to add an overview session of all the topics we have done at the end of the semester because everything can get messy with the amount of material we cover.

Absolutely! This course has been the most amazing class I have taken here at Yale. And the professor is incredible! Just be prepared to work hard, and you will be immersed in an incredible environment!

100% recommend if you are a STEM student interested in learning biology, and you need a writing credit. This is not an easy class at all, and definitely feels like a difficult science class rather than a writing class. Do NOT take this class if you do not have a good background in biology, you will be very confused. Also the field trip to NYC was very fun.
Yes, the lectures are very interesting.

This class literally changed my life. It convinced me that cancer research was what I wanted to do for my career; it was an incredibly fascinating and fulfilling class from start to finish, and Dean Chang is a great professor and mentor to have. Absolutely, 100% take this class! It's unlike any other first-year seminar at Yale.

Absolutely yes!!!!! This was the best course I have taken so far at Yale. If you are on the waitlist, just email Dean Chang immediately. I learned so much about cancer, and this course really helped stimulate excitement for science and biology. I loved learning about all the mechanisms and structural biology behind cancer and learning about the complexity of cancer. Also, some of the material learned, such as immunotherapy, is very current and relevant. Sometimes after lectures, I would get chills and cannot stop thinking about a certain treatment we discussed or the way cancer behaves. I was so challenged, and I was able to grow so much. Even the way he structures his class to make it interactive, such as with the Game of Thrones groups, made our class so close, and I was able to make so many friends. Dean Chang is also accessible and takes us out to food all the time, and he also took us on a tour of the Cushing Center. I cannot emphasize how great this class was in general, and this course will continue to influence my future.
I would definitely recommend this course because I developed skills that have been positive in other aspects of my academic career, especially for premed students.
I would!
Absolutely!! Truly a lovely, intellectually challenging class.

Absolutely incredible course. The best decision I made Freshman year was to take this. If you are at all even a little interested in Biology you should strongly consider taking this course. Before this course I wasn't sure if I was interested in pursuing one of the biology majors. Taking this course inspired me to pursue one of the biology majors.
Yes, especially if they are considering a degree in science because it helps envision what exactly that would look like.

Definitely would, as long as the student is interested in science/medicine. I learned a lot and found every class to be interesting and engaging. I also appreciated that a lot of what we learned in class was directly applicable to things I hope to do in the future (such as writing a research proposal).
I would 100% recommend this course. Not only is the material fascinating, but Dean Chang is an amazing teacher in both presenting and forming relationships with his students.

I was a student who came into this class with an interest in biology and wanted to explore the world of cancer more. However, I knew that I wasn't going to be going to med school or majoring in MCDB. Even though I knew less about the research methods in biology and all the assays, I can confidently say that I got just as much out of this class.

If you have a genuine interest in biology and don't want to sit through the biology sequence, this is a perfect class for you. Cancer is a niche field, however, the topics and research methods discussed in the class apply outside of cancer.
If you want a very rewarding but challenging course, this is the one for you. Even those with little bio knowledge were able to keep up as long as they put in the work.
